div1.p: AS IT IS ACTED AT THE THEATRE ROYAL, COVENT-GARDEN.
DUBLIN: Printed by N. Kelly, For P. WOGAN, P. BYRNE, J. MOORE, W. JONES, J. RICE, T. M'DONNEL, J. JONES, G. FOLINGSBY, and N. KELLY.

lg.l: FRUITFUL in good and ill, the teaming earth
To wheat and tares affords promiscuous birth:
At once, from nature's womb, rise woe and weal;
The springs that poison, and the streams that heal.
Nay more, her offspring each and all contain,
Within themselves, both antidote and bane.
Each is a jarring world, where death yields life;
And concord rises out of endless strife.
Each seems distinct, yet all together bound:
And separate and collectively is found
A hoard of infinite; a countless mass
Of miracles within a blade of grass.
First of the tribe, and master of the whole,
Man stands erect; the sovereign and the soul.
In him all union and disunion shine:
He's now above half brute; now more than half divine.
Wayward in humour; infinite in wit;
The slave of all, to none will he submit;
In act an idiot; in conceit a sage;
Mov'd by a breath, he'll brave the tempest's rage;
Now soar, a demi-god; now sink, a straw;
Now weep, a child; now give the planets law.
Railing at wretchedness, in folly wise,
Alive to all the bliss that he denies,
Worthy your laughter or perhaps your tears,
Brain-sick of errors past, to night appears
A moody mortal; sketch'd on this mad plan;
A surly misanthrope, and yet a man.
Within his orbit other beings move;
Some urg'd by av'rice, others spurr'd by love,
To aid or injure him, as passion drives;
The worst of servants; and the best of wives:
With many more, all waiting here within;
My task being ended, ready to begin.
Hear, and decide, like men who think and feel:
For, from this night's decree, there's no appeal.

sp.speaker: DONALD.
sp.p: GIN the black de'el glowr at me, I'ze tell ye my mind! Dischairge me an ye wull: I a been nae mair but therty years i' the faimily. I care nae for yeer canker'd girns! An ye wad nae hear fashus tales, ye munna be guilty o' fow deeds!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Will you speak in a lower key?—Earth is wholly inhabited by Harpies, and I am eternally haunted by the most malignant of them!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: An I get nae tidings of her to-day, I'ze advertize for her i' the public papers! Ay, and I'ze gar yeer name be imprented at full langth!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Print my name?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: The de'el hike me on his horns gin I dunna.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Daemon! I'll blow your brains out!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Fiz, wi' your flash i' the pan! I dunna fear ye! Yeer rash and mad enoch! Sham betide ye! A father abandon his child?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Leprosy seize your licentious tongue, will you speak lower? Did I abandon her?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Ye wad nae acknowledge her; wad nae see her; never frae the time that she war a wee tot at the knee! Gin ye had a hairt ye wad nae aixpose her tul.—

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Tramp the streets! Aixpald the warld of onesty by her ain father! And why, trow? She is a naitural child! To beget children, and then turn them adrift to bag, steal or stairve, is a damned unnaitural deed!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Prophet of evil! Would you tell all the family? Expose me to my wife?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I'ze aixpose ye tul the whole warld, gin I dunna find her! And what the muckle better shall I be gin I do? A thrawart poverty maun be her lot! Ye ha' diced, and drabbed, and squandered, and mortgaged, till ye wull na' hae a baw bee tul yeersal!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Cease your croaking, raven! Do you govern this house, or I?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Govern, trow? Belzebub himsal is the governor! There is yeer pett steward! An auld whilly wha! Tak warning! I ha' toud ye aforetime and I tell ye again, he's a rascal.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Viper, 'tis false! If the earth hold an honest man, Mr. item is he.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Onest? A juggling loon o'hell! He feigns to borrow the filler for ye wetch he lends himsal; and the walthy possassions ye lang syne held wull estsoon be aw his ain.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I say 'tis false! His truth, integrity and zeal are unexampled!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Marcy o' God, ye'er bewetched!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What a den of misery is this world! Swarming with one set of fiends that raise the whirlwind of the passions, and with another that beset and tantalize the bewildered wretch for having been overtaken by the storm!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Poor Joanna! Winsom lassey—I'ze keep my ward!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Can nothing stop your pestiferous tongue? Have I not fifty times descended to explanation, and shewn you that I must not, cannot, own her?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Dare not! Ye hanna the hairt to be onest! Ye bogle at shadows!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Pertinacious devil! The public clamour and disgrace, the affected sufferings and insulting forbearance of Lady Anne, the resentment of her imperious family, are these shadows?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: What is it you are pleased to be talking, pray, about my lady, Mr. Scotch Donald?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Troth, Mrs. English Sarsnet, nae ward o' ill.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: Ill truly! No, sir, my lady may defy her worst enemies! Though there are folks, who ought to adore the very ground she treads upon, that use her like a Turk!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: How now?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: I name no names.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Who sent for you here, Mistress?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: My lady sent me here, sir.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: And did she bid you behave with impertinence?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: She, indeed! A dear suffering saint! She bid me always behave with affability and decorum: and so I would, if I could But it would provoke an angel!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: And what is it your wisdom thinks so provoking!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: To see a sweet lady sit for hours, and pine and grieve; and then, when some folks are in sight, pretend to smile and be all assignation and contentment, when all the while her poor heart is ready to break!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Then she complains to you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: I said no such thing, sir! No: she complains to no christian foul; more's the shame! I wish some folks had a little of my spirit! other folks, mayhap, mut find the difference!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Troth, an yee wad nae be sneaking o' that, Mrs. Sarsnet.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: A poor weak woman, who can only take her own part by crying, and fainting!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Ye forget, Mrs. Sarsnet, there are some poor weak women that ha' tongues and nails.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: Have they, Mr. Snap-short? Why then, if I had you for a husband, mayhap I would let you see that I could use them.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: The muckle de'el may doubt yee!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: It's a shame, Mr. Donald, for you to be getting into corners, and whispering and peering and plotting to my lady's dishonour!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I plotting? How dare yee, Mrs. Sarsnet.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Silence, with you both!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: You ought to be ashamed of making yourself a spy, and a skip-jack go-between!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I a skip-jack? Varra weel! Yee hear, sir, what are my thanks! 'Tis unco weel! I hae but my desairts! True enoch, I am a go-between!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: Yes, yes; we know that very well, Mr. Donald.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: But nae sic go-between as yee, Mrs. Malapert, may thenk me! I hae been a trust worthy caterer tul the family: (To Mordent.) a slave tul yeer revels, and yeer roots, and year banquetings. 'Tis lang syne ye made me yeer purveyor; but nae man ever yet made me his pander!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Begone! See if Mr. Item is returned.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: Ah! There's another!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Skip-jack? Go-between? Mag's malison o' yeer spitefoo' tongue-gab!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Did your lady, I say, instruct you to behave with this insolence?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: You know very well, sir, my lady is the best of wives! she sent me on a civil message, and bid me speak with properiety: and so, if speaking one's mind and telling the truth be a fault, its all my own.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I'll put an end to this.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: Oh, to be sure; you may tell my lady and get me turned away, if you please! because, I know very well, if you bid her, she will do it!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Prometheus and his vulture is no fable!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: But, as it is all for love of my lady, I am sure the Earl of Olderest, her father, will give me a sitiation He knows, mayhap, more than you may think. So does the Viscount her brother, too; her aunt lady Mary, and her uncle the Bishop: and every body is not obliged to be so blind and so tame as my lady!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What is it they know?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: That's more than I can say; but they have all been here, and my lady desires to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Indeed!—I have no leisure.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: Ha! I told my lady so!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Begone! inform your lady, I have tormentors enough; and have no inclination to increase the number.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: I prognostified the answer!—A good for nothing chap!—I know very well what is becoming of a husband! He should love his wife, dearly, by day and by night! he should wait upon her; and give her her own way; and keep her from the cold, and the wet; and provide her with every thing comfortable; and if the happen to be in an ill humour, should coax her, and bear a little snubbing patiently! Humph! The fellows! What are they good for?

head.stage: SCENE IV. Changes to the Steward's Room.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: My dear Grime, I am glad you are come! Well, is the deed prepared?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Ready for sealing. Mr. Mordent never examines what he signs! he trusts all to you!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: We cannot be too safe. But, this other affair? this Joanna? What have you done? Have you decoyed her to Mrs. Enfield's?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Really, Mr. Item, she is so fine a creature that, when I consigned her over, I am not a true Christian if I did not feel such a twinge here!—

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Curse your twinges? Is she safe? Did she suspect nothing?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: No, no! The poor innocent blessed herself, to think what a kind protectress Providence had sent her?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: That is well! That is well!

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: But I do not yet understand why you should seek the ruin of this lovely creature?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: I? You mistake: 'tis Mr. Mordent!

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: What, wish destruction to his child?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: No, no. We neither of us seek her harm; but our own safety.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Which way?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: He has various tormentors; his wife, or rather her proud relations, are among the chief; and he dreads they should come to the knowledge of this secret. But his strongest terror is of being detected, in having for years disowned a child who, if now produced, would be his everlasting disgrace.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Then he does not know that his daughter is now in the house of Mrs. Enfield?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Not a word. His plan, for the present, is to settle her in some profession: for this he will bestow a thousand pounds, which, ha, ha, ha! I am to expend.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Or keep?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Plague! I have said too much.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Oh, oh! A thousand pounds?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: That—that, my dear Grime, would be a paltry motive.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: I'll have my share!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Mr. Mordent has been all his life squandering, like a blockhead, what I have been prudently picking up.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: And pretty pickings you have had, Mr. Item!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p:
I have him in the toils! Interest accumulating, upon interest, and all in arrear. I can foreclose upon him when I please, for all except the Berkshire estate; and by this second mortgage, agreeably to the deed you have brought, equity of redemption
will be forfeited, and that as well as the rest will then be mine!

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: If he had but signed and sealed—

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Which he shall do this very day.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Still, why are you the enemy of Joanna? What have you to sear from her?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Much! Very much! An action of recovery!

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: How so? She has no title! She is illegitimate!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Would she were! No, no; a lawful daughter, born in wedlock; her mother poor but virtuous, and died in childbed. Fearful it should injure his second marriage with lady Anne, he never produced the infant, but told his man, Donald, it was a natural daughter, and by his intermission secretly maintained and had her educated.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Why not employ the same agent still?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Because this Donald has got the fool's disease, pity, and threatens to make Mordent own his daughter, or impeach.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: And it was prudent to place her beyond Donald's knowledge?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: It was.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Ha! 'Tis a strange world! Well, now, Mr. Item, give me leave to say a word or two on my own affairs.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: To be sure my dear friend! Speak and spare not.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: There is the thousand pounds, you mentioned.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Hem!

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Then the premium on this mortgage—In short, Mr. Item, I do all your business, stand in your shoes;—

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: You are my right hand, the apple of my eyes!

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Ay, but—

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: The dearest friend I have on earth!

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: The division of profits—

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Don't mention it. Am not I your friend? I shall not live for ever.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: No, nor I neither. Friendship—

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Don't think of it. You can't distrust me! The first and best friend you ever had!

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Fine words—

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Yonder is my nephew. (Calls.) Clement.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Fetch the title deeds of the Berkshire estate from my good friend Mr. Grime's.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Well, but—

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Any time, to-day.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Very well, sir.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Once again, Mr. Item—

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: And, Clement!

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: I say the division—

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Hark! I hear Mr. Mordent!

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: It shall not pass off thus. I begin to know you!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: I would not have you seen just now—My dear Grime! My kind friend! Through this door! Some other opportunity! Pray oblige me!

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Well, well— (Aside.) The next time we meet, you shall know more of my mind.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: The rascal begins to grow troublesome!—Take care of the steps, good Mr. Grime!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p:
What is life? A continual cloud; pregnant with mischief, malignity, disease and death. Happiness? An ignis fatuus. Pleasure? A nonentity. Existence? A misfortune, a burthen. None but fools condescend to live. Men exert their whole faculties to torture one another. Animals are the prey of animals. Flowers bloom to be plucked and perish. The very grass grows to be torn and eaten: trees to be mangled, sawed, rooted up, and burned. The whole is a system of exquisite misery, and I have my full proportion!—Oh! this girl! Why am I thus perturbed concerning her; She can but be wretched; and wretchedness is the certain sate of all! But then, the world? Why what an insatuated ass am I; contemning
the world and all it contains, yet living in continual dread of its reproof!

Well, my good Mr. Item, this poor Joanna! What have you done? Can you secure her happiness? Pshaw! Fool! Can you lighten her misery? I can think of nothing but her; though distraction is in every thought?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: 'Tis a serious affair: very serious—you ought to do nothing lightly.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Turned adrift, rejected of all, no relation, no friend, never acknowledged, never?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: My advice you know, Sir, was at once boldly to produce her, as your daughter. No matter for the impertinent clamours and questions of who her mother was, and what became of her; why the child was never owned; where she had been concealed, and for what purposes?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ay, ay, ay! The malignant sneers of friends, the cutting calumny of enemies, the reproaches of Lady Anne, the insults of her pompous proud family!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: For my part, I obey your commands, but I cannot approve them.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: My late ward, Mr. Cheveril, should he hear of it what would he think?—Then this Berkshire mortgage!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Ay, there again! Totally opposite to my advice.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Can you shew me any other possible way of paying my debts?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: The danger of signing it is extreme!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: 'Tis ruin! But what matter? Is not the whole one mass of wretchedness?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Young Cheveril, I own, has demands.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Which must be paid.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Then the out-standing bills—tradesmen are provokingly insolent!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ay, ay! They, like the rest, have their appointed office of torture!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Well, remember I have given you fair warning!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p:
Certainly! You do your part, and with the
best intentions; goad, and sting, and add your quantum to the sum of suffering! The consistency of evil is amazing! good and bad, all concur!—Is the deed ready?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: I must first read it through.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Do so. I leave it all to you.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: But that will not take ten minutes.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I will be back presently. The gulph is before me, plunge I must, and to plunge blindfold will be to cheat the devil of some part of the pain!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Nay, if you will not be warned, it is not my fault.

div3.head: SCENE VII. The Dressing Room of Lady ANNE.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: I told your Ladyship he would refuse.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: What reason did he give?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: Reason, forsooth! Husbands never have any reason!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Unkind man! Why does he thus wish to avoid me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: He keeps his distance, both day and night! But I would teach him to sleep in two beds! A pretty fashon truly! I would tell him I was afraid of ghosts; and so I married because I could not nor I would not lie alone. So let him remember that.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Why were you so long in bringing the message back?.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: Why that is what I have to tell your Ladyship. If there is not bad doings, say I am no witch.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: Your Ladyship must not be angry; but you know I can't help having a sharp eye and a quick ear of my own.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: What have you been doing now?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: So I saw my Master go into the steward's room.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Pshaw! Folly! What of that?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: So I had all my seven senses and my eye-teeth about me.—

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Pray have done!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: So I clapped my ear to the keyhole; and then I heard a—whuz, buz—

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: This was very improper!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: So I could only catch up a word here and there; and the first was summut about—of a child!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: A child?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: And a mother, my Lady! Though for the matter of that, where there is a child, one's own nataral penetrality will tell one there must be a mother.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Of what weakness am I guilty?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: And I thought I catched the sound of Mr. Item of a fathering the child! and I'm posituve he said it wuz against his conscience!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Who said so?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: Mr. Item, my Lady! And so a little bit after, my master called somebody a poor injurious girl, and a prodigality of wit and beauty! So then I heard somebody's foot on the stairs, and I wuz fain to scamper.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: I know not why I listen to this indecent prattle! My over-anxious curiosity betrays me, and you are much too forward to profit by my weakness.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: Because you know, my Lady, I love you in my heart; and it is all for your own good.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: A child! An injured girl! Yet why do I feel agitation? His infidelities have been too open, for me to be ignorant of them. And who has been to blame; he or I? Oh! doubtful and difficult question!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: But I'll come at the truth, I'll warrant me, in all its particlers!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Suffering perhaps under the consciousness of error, which the sight of me might increase, he flies from additional anguish. Oh! that I had the power to sooth and reconcile him to himself! Why will he not receive consolation from me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: I'll rummage about.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: If I am unhappy, how must I be certain that it is not my own fault? Where there is unhappiness, neither party can be wholly blameless.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: He ought to love and adore such a Lady! and clothe her in satin and gold!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Shall I tyrannize over the affections that I cannot win? If I want the power to please, let me correct my own defects, and not accuse my husband of insensibility! Oh, nothing is so killing to a husband's love, as a discontented, irksome, wailing wife! let me be any thing but that!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: He is a barbarian Turk! and so I as good as told him.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: What is the test of an affectionate wife? It is that, being wronged, her love remains undiminished; having cause of complaint, she scorns to complain, convinced that any misery is more welcome than the possibility of becoming the torment of her bosom's Lord! Oh, let me rather suffer every possible evil than endure my husband's hate!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: If any fellow was to use me so, I know what I would do.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Yet have I not lost his love? Dreadful doubt! My family advise a separation, and, if this fatal loss be real, how is it to be avoided? Yet, I will not sightly yield! Let me hope my efforts will not all be ineffectual. Would this agonizing contest were ended!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: She may say what she will, but I know very well she is the most miserable-est lady alive, and I could tear his eyes out! Husband, indeed? And so, because I listened to the fellow's love, and nonsensestuff, and took pity on him, when he was going to hang or drown himself, he must think, as soon as he has got me safe, to be my lord and master! I'd tell him another story! My lord and master, truly!

div3.head: SCENE I. The House of Mrs. ENFIELD.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ENFIELD.
sp.p: AND, mind me, treat her with great kindness and deference.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I'll be careful.

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: Keep her in continual good humour: don't let her ask for any thing twice; and above all things listen to her complaints, and pity them.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: My white handkerchief shall be at her service.

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: Is the messenger returned?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Yes, madam; and there is no answer from Mr. Mordent, but Mr. Lennox sent word he will soon be here.

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: Send her to me.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Yes, madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: She is young, and ignorant of the town; but, I can see, she has a quick and courageous spirit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: Well, my sweet Joanna; do you think you can love me, and trust me, and follow my advice?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Are you not my benevolent protectress, and will it not be my duty?

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: Why that's a precious! Ay, ay; do but as I desire you, darling, and then!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Oh, that I will! Come, set me to work.

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: Ah, I won't kill you with work. Pretty dear! Those delicate arms!—They were not made for work.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Fie! You must not tell me that. My mother is dead, and my father—! (firmly.) But I must bear my fate with fortitude. Labour is no punishment.

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p:
Labour? Oh the beauty! Chicken gloves, my lamb, for those white hands! A noble looking-glass,
to see that sweet form! A fine chariot, to shew off your charms! These you ought to have, and a thousand other fine things. Ay, and if you will take my advice, have them you shall.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Fine things? Chariots? No, no; not for me. To work, to work.—But I'll willingly take your advice; for are so kind, it cannot be ill!

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: Ill? Heaven protect me! I advise a dear sweet handsome creature to ill?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Handsome? Fie! an orphan; Fatherless!

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: Ay, very true! Ill? No, no; think me your parent.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Dear lady!

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: Ah, my tender lamb! Think of joy! Think of pleasure!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Be not so kind. You should not soften, but steel my heart! Teach it to have neither fear nor feeling of wrong; to laugh when others weep. Oh! I'll mock at sorrow!

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: Do not think of it.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Did you never see your father?

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: Anan, dear?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: I never saw mine! Do not even know his name! I had a strange desire to see him once, but once, and I was denied! I am a high spirited girl, but I would have kneeled to him; would have kissed his feet; and was refused.—No matter!

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: Forget it.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Well, well!—Courage!—You must let me work. I'll earn what I eat. I love you for your kindness, but I will not be dependent.

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: Since you will! You say you can draw?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: It has been my delight. I have studied the human countenance, have read Lavater.

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: Anan! Will you copy the engraving I shewed you?—

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: What, the portrait of that strange—?

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: Mr. Mordent.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Mordent?

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: Of Portland Place.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: I don't quite like him!

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: He's a wicked man.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: Nay—

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: A wild eye!—I hope he is not your relation.

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: No; but has been a very good friend.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Take care of him!

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: Can you judge so certainly?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Looking at such a face, who can fail? (Examining Mrs. Einfield.) You are a worthy lady; a kind lady; your actions bespeak it: and yet—Don't be angry—there is something about your features—that I don't like!

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: Bless, me, dear!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: In must be wrong, because you are good: but you have not a good countenance. That's strange! I never saw such a thing before!—And the more I look the less I like.

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: Does she suspect me?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: If ever I draw your face, I'll alter some of the lines. I'll make them such as I think virtue ought to have made them; open, honest, undaunted. You have such a number of little artful wrinkles at the corners of your eves!—You are very cunning!

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: What does she mean?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: But what of that? You are kind to me; and I sear no cunning, not I! You found me friendless, have given me work, and I would die to serve you! So I'll copy that wild man's portrait.

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: Wild?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Nay, for that matter, you need not fear him; but if you know any vain, foolish young girls, that love flaunting, and will listen to fine promises, bid them beware of him!

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: A little witch.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Mr. Lennox is below, madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: I am glad of that! Come, my sweet Joanna, I'll introduce you to him.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Me, madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: Ay, Child! that I will. Every body shall know what an angel my dear young friend is.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Consider, madam—

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: Nay, I am sure you will not refuse me this pleasure? Come, come!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: You are too kind!

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: Come, my precious.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Well! I commit myself to your trust. Friendless and fatherless, you will be my guardian. You are too generous to injure the helpless, and the forlorn: and the lines in your face are false!

div3.head: SCENE III. An Anti-chamber in the House of MORDENT.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Grumble no more 'Guardy! Have done with prognosticating evil! 'Tis all in vain: your gloomy reign is ended: I am of age!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: To play the fool!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: I'm free! I'm alive! I'm beginning to exist!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Like a wretch at the stake, when the flames first reach him!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: The whole world is before me! its pleasures are spread out, and I long to fall on! The golden apples of delight hang inviting me to pluck, eat, and—

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Be poisoned!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: As your guardian, I—

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Damn guardianship! I have been guarded too long. Years our of number have I been fed with lean Latin, crabbed Greek, and an abominable olio of the four faculties; served up with the jargon of Aristotle, the quirks of Thomas Aquinas, and the quibbles and quodlibets of Doctor Duns Scotus.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Take warning—!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Fined for Horace, horsed for Homer, and plucked because I could not parrot over their premises and predicates, majors and minors, antecedents and consequents. My brain was a broker's shop; the little good furniture it contained all hid by lumber!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Let me tell you, young Sir—

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Not now: Your day is done. I am my own man! I breathe! I am abroad! I am on the wing to visit the regions of fruition and Paradise; to banquet with the Gods, and sip ambrosia from the lips of Venus and Hebe, the Hours, the Loves, and the Graces!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: You are a lunatic!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: No! I am just come to my senses; for I am just come to my estate! High health, high spirits, eight thousand a year, and one and twenty!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Youth? Riches? Poor ideot! Health too? What is man but a walking hospital? You, boy, you, little as you suspect it, include within yourself a whole pharmacopoeia of malady and mischief!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Zounds! He'll persuade me presently I am Pandora's box!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: So you are!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Why, guardy! You are mad!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: True, or I should take the shortest way to get rid of misery, and instantly go hang myself!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: What a picture!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Equal it in accuracy, if you can.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Why I am but a young artist; however I can dash my brush at the canvas as daringly as you have done! So what think you (Rapturously) of mirth, songs, and smiles; youth, beauty, and kisses; friendship, liberty, and love; with a large capacious soul of benevolence, that can sooth the afflicted, succour the poor, heal the sick, instruct the ignorant, honour the wise, reform the bad, adore the good, and hug genius and virtue to the heart?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Every feature a lie!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Curse me but I say the likeness is at least as good as yours: and I am sure the colouring is infinitely more delightful!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I'ze ganging aboot the business of the poor lassy, ken ye me? Gin ye want me, I'ze be back in a blink.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Go to the devil, if you will; so that you do not torment me.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Ha, friend Donald! Don't you know that I'm of age? Won't you revel and roar, my boy? Why do you look so glum, old honesty?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Troth ye mistake the maitter, young gentleman: I am an auld go-between.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: It's varra true; wetch makes me unco blate. A helpless bairn has been cast upo' the wide warld, by a hairtless father, and I am a pairt o' the cause.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Again, Imp?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: A child deserted by the father!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Ye well may shew the gogle o' yeer eyn.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Is he poor? Is he pennyless?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Much thereaboot, an I dunna miss my ken.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Bring the child to me! Bring it to me, old rueful! I'll be it's father! I never fathered a child in my life, and I long to begin!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Ye seem truly to hae mair human affaction than some fathers.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Begone! Leave us, Blood-sucker! Goblin! Vampire!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Yas—I'ze gang where I tow'd ye; and, gin I dunna hear o'her, ye'ze hear o' me!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Bring me the baby, Donald! Zounds how it would delight me to father all the fatherless children in the world? Poor little dears! I should have a plentiful brood!—And so, guardian, I want money.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What! To purchase destruction wholesale?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: I have five hundred good, wicked, spirited, famous projects on hand. You have seventeen thousand pounds of mine, hard cash. I want it.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Seventeen thousand plagues!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Every farthing.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Your money, sir, is locked up in mortgages.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Locked up? Oh, damme, I'll unlock it. I'll send honest Grime to ye; he carries a master key.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Have you no regard to my convenience.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p:
I'll pay the premium; and, if you want security, you may have mine. I must have money!
The world must hear of me! I'll be a patron, and a subscriber, and a collector, and an amateur, and a connoisseur, and a dilletanti! I'll hunt, I'll race, I'll dice; I'll grub, plant, plan, and improve! I'll buy a stud, fell a forest, build a palace, and pull down a church.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Mr. Cheveril!—He is flown—Why ay, with spirits equally wild, wanton, and ignorant of evil, I began my career. I have now lived long enough to discover that universal nature is universal agony! O this rejected Joanna ! Miserable girl! Well? Am not I miserable too? Who is not?—The dangers to which she may be exposed? The cruelty of utterly abandoning her? Never shall I again be at peace with myself?—

sp.speaker: Lady. A
sp.p: Where is your master?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Hark! My wife! She tortures me with her silent sufferings and her stifled sighs. Passion, bitter reproach, and violent menace, would be infinitely more supportable. In short, I have not deserved her kindness, and cannot endure it.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Mr. Mordent! Thus does he continually shun me! Why then do I haunt him? Why intrude myself upon him?—Must this have no end? Fond foolish heart, these aches and pains are fruitless! Sleep in forgetfulness, cease to feel, and be at peace!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: I tell you, I can't stay!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: The stories, too, with which this kind but officious creature torments me—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: I've got it, my lady! I've got it!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: What is the matter now?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: Why, I'll tell your ladyship. A queer quandary kind of person brought my master a letter; which I knew was suspicious. So my master's coat was all powder; over here. (significantly.) How he came by it, I don't know!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Pshaw! Pray don't teaze me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: So, my lady, he took it off, and ordered one of the fellows to give it a brush. So, making a pretence, I was close at his heels.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: At whose heels?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: The footman's, my lady. So while he was brushing, he had a wranglation with the cook; and turned about to gabble footman's gibberish with she; so I, having a hawk's eye, twirled my hand behind me; so; and felt in the pocket; and there I found this written letter, which I slily slipped under my apron; so—

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Take a letter out of your master's pocket?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: Yes, my lady; because, being broke open, I read the contents, and found that it was from one Mrs. Enfield, to appoint an assassination between my master and a young girl.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Give it me!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: Yes, my lady; I was sure you could not but wish to see it.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Mistress Sarsnet, I have frequently cautioned you against practices like these; which are mean, dishonest, and pilfering.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: My lady!

sp.speaker: Lady. A.
sp.p: To have robbed your master of his money would have been less culpable, than to steal from him the knowledge of transactions which, because of their impropriety, he has not the courage to avow.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.stage: (Whimpering, and with tokens of great affection.)
sp.p: It's very hard, because I can't bear your lady—ladyship's ill usage, and, and, and always feel as if my very stays were a bursting, to see your, your treatment, time after time—that I should get myself ill, ill, ill-will, because I love you from the very bottom of my heart!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: I have winked at these liberties too often: I'll suffer them no longer.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: Very—very well—Since your ladyship is so angry, you may turn, turn, me away, if you please and quite break, break, break my heart!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: No: the fault is more than half my own: But, from this time, I seriously warn you against such improper, such base actions.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: Very—very well, my lady! I'll be deaf, and dumb, and blind! and, when I see you treated worser than a savage, I'll burst twenty laces a day, before I'll speak a word!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: What you have done has been affectionately meant. I am sorry to have given you pain, and to have excited your tears. But I must earnestly desire you will commit no more such mistakes. They are wrong, in themselves; and every way fatal to my peace.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: You are the tenderest and best of ladies! and I know who is an unfeeling brute!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Pray, mistress Sarsnet, is Mr. Mordent within?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: Indeed, sir, I don't know! (Muttering) Mr. Mordent is a good for nothing chap!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: I'll bet you a thousand, Cheveril, your charmer does not equal the girl I have this moment left.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Done, for ten thousand!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: You would lose.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: You never beheld so peerless a beauty!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: How did you become acquainted with her?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: We are not yet acquainted; (Sighs) and I begin to fear we never shall be.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Oh, oh!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: I met her three times in the Green Park. The first moment I gazed at her with admiration—as soon as she was gone by!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Gone by?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Good manners, you know, would not let me stare her in the face. Such a shape! Such elegance I The next time I determined to speak to her, and approached as resolutely as Hercules to the Hydra.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: A good simile for a beauty!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: I had studied a speech; but, somehow, there was such a sweet severity in her looks—I—I had not the power to utter a word!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Courageous lover!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: The third time however, it being a little darker, for it was always in the evening, I was more undaunted: so, fully determined to throw myself at her feet and declare my passion, up I marched! But, as the devil would have it, she turned and looked me full in the face; and her beauty, and—and virtue—and—and modesty, were so awful—that my heart sunk within me!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: It is now a fortnight since; and, though I have walked the Green Park, morning, noon and night every day, I could never once again set eyes on her! Intolerable booby that I was, to lose three such precious opportunities!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Of making love to a lady's maid?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Oh for one momentary glance, that I might give vent to the passion that devours me!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: What! You think I dare not?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Look you, Cheveril, I know you: a lighted match and the mouth of a cannon could not cow you like the approach of a petticoat.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: I!—Afraid of women? Damme, I don't understand having my character attacked and traduced! Make a Master Jackey of me? I am a wicked one!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Wicked? You are as conscientious as a drunken methodist, or as a dying miser! You are not only afraid of the woman but of the sin!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Why, if—No, damme, 'tis not true! I have no more conscience than yourself.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Me? I have a deal of conscience. Pleasure, I own, can tempt me; but I make no pretensions, like you, to sin for the sake of reputation.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p:
Sir, I make no such pretensions! I am, indeed, resolved to be a fellow of enterprize, pith, and soul; but not by vile rascally methods. I'll love all the women, and perhaps trick some of the men; but
not seduce wives, ruin daughters, and murder husbands and fathers. No! If I cannot be wicked without being criminal, damme if I do not live and die an honest dull dog.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Curse the letter—It's gone—Careless booby.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: A thousand to one but it has fallen into the hands of lady Anne!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: What have you lost?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: A damned epistle, from—

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Hem!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Mr. Mordent, I am glad to meet with you!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Glad? Is the thing so difficult?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: I did not say so: I meant nothing unkind.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Indeed I did not—I wish to speak to you.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Stay where you are, Lennox. What, man you are in no fear of soothing insult! You are not married.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: I'll return in five minutes.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Mordent—

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Pshaw! I know I am a bear at the stake: don't shorten my tether.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: I have a paper—

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ay, ay! I knew it. Come, begin! I am prepared.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: It fell into my hands by the reprehensible but unauthorized curiosity of my woman.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Indeed, I have never opened it.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Nor she either!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Yes; but that is not my fault.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Yours indeed? Impossible!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: The heart, which I cannot secure by affection, I will not alienate by suspecting.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Pshaw! Meekness is but mockery, forbearance insult.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: How shall I behave? Which way frame my words and looks, so as not to offend? Would I could discover?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: You never complain? You have no jealousy?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Indeed, I have been very obstinately blind.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ay, ay! Patience on a monument!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Reproach, at least, has never escaped my lips.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! As if lips were the only instruments of upbraiding! No deep fetched sighs? No pale melancholy glances? No obvious hiding of the ever ready tear?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: I fear I have been to blame! Indeed, I am sorry that my sensations have been so acute.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: You accuse? You give a husband pain? Insolent supposition!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: I sincerely wish, my dear, you gave no more than I intend to give!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: There! Did not I say so? Ha, ha, ha! You accuse?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: I am wrong! I forgot myself! Pray forgive me! Why am I subject to these mistakes?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: You are all angel!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Would I were!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: And I all demon!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Do not, Mr. Mordent, by the dear affection you once bore—

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: There! There! The affection I once bore?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Heavens! Must I ever be fated to wound, when it is most the wish of my soul to heal?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Why was the Earl of Oldcrest here, this morning? Why are these family consultations held?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: They are contrary to my wish.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: A separation, I hear, is the subject of them?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: But not countenanced by me.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Pretending in pity to spare me yourself, they are to be set upon me!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Never! Heaven be my judge, never!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I am to be subjected to their imperious dictates!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: I own they have lately been very urgent with me, to return to my father; but, were you only kind, their solicitations would be vain indeed. Oh! take pity on yourself and me, and teach me to regain your lost affections! or if that be too great a blessing to hope, there is still one evil, which I would suffer any other torture to escape. Think, if you can, that I no longer love; treat me with unkindness; neglect, accuse, do any thing—but hate me! Let me not endure that last stage of misery! But—Oh heavens!—if our former endearments must end in that, have mercy, and retard or conceal it as long as you can!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! What are barbs, and stings, and poisoned arrows? Pitiful instruments! Thou, triumphant wretchedness, usest these but on small occasions; they want pungency!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: May I come in?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ay, ay!—Now am I ripe for mischief!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: You seem out of temper! What has happened?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Trifles, trifles! She has got the letter.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: From whom?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Mrs. Endfields!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Zounds!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: An invitation to a new sample of beauty. She has seen it; returned it; has graciously forgiven; has racked, has driven me mad!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: And do you mean to go?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ay will I! Since devil I am, devil let me be! It will be some, though but a petty vengeance for prying.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: You must not.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Indeed but I will.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: We have long been friends, and fellow-sinners; but, in these affairs, we have always behaved hohourably.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: I have seen the girl!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: At Enfield's.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Did she write to you, too?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: She did. An angel, Mordent!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: An angel! I am seriously and deeply smitten.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Marry her, and make wretchedness secure!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: No; but I am fixed for life. Such animation! Such soul! The finest creature my eyes ever beheld!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I'll see her.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: No; I cannot consent.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Why so? I'll aid you to carry her off.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Are you serious?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: As malice can make me! The sex have been worse to me than plague, pestilence, and famine!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: And what have you been to them?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No matter: I'll have my revenge!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: And you will aid me in this business?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Solemnly? on your word and honour?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I tell you, I will!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Why then; see her you shall; but in my company, observe.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Right! anticipate your torments!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: On this condition, I shall thank you for your assistance and advice.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Why ay! Advice! I too, fool that I am, knowing the impotence of man to avert mischief, I wish for advice! I— (Aside.) There may be danger in telling him?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: A—A friend of mine has a child; suppose it a—a natural child; that he knows not how properly to dispose of.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: A natural child, that he knows not how properly to dispose of?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Could not he sell it to the kidnappers?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Pshaw!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: There are honest overseers that will take it, fifty pounds down!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Not an infant: twenty years of age.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Oh! Then indeed! There are crimp serjeants!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: When I put a serious question, I expect a serious answer.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Serious! And ask what a man is to do with his child!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Suppose he should have legitimate offspring?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Oh, oh! Legitimate! Hah! Made of other metal? A different manufacture?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: You won't hear! He provided for her.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: A female, too?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Would have continued to provide, but she rejected his assistance.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Unless he would see her, embrace her; that is, whine over, acknowledge her, and bestow his blessing.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: And he refused?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Why not? Of what benefit are blessings? Where all is evil, why torment conscience concerning the mode?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: He is a monster!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: But, sir, appearances—

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Damn appearances.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Friends—

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Damn his friends!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: A wife—

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Damn his wife! He has friends, appearances, and a wife; but he has no heart!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: She is gone! She is lost for aye! I'ze e'en red wude!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: How now? Herald of malice and mischief!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I canna foregether her! Fair fa' yeer hairt! I'ze ne'er set eyes o' her mair.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Peace, hound!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I tell you I wunna! Misca' me an ye wull, the de'el ma' care! A father turn his back o' his bairn!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Oh, ho! What it was yourself, your own daughter, you were talking of?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Gin earth haud her, I'ze hae her yet; ay and I'ze gar ye do her recht. (Return.) She laft a massige for ye!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What message?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Tell him, gin he wunna gi his child ane kess, ane scrimpet blassing, that child wull wark, stairve and die, ore she wull leve like a parish pauper on scraps and alms. Tell him she has a pridefoo' spirit, that wunna bag, gin she canna win: and, gif he scorn his dochtor, she scorns aksapt his charity.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: So you commit crime, and then invent a system for its justification? Excellent philosopher!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Why dunna ye spier a'ter her yeersal? Hech! Waesucks! Ye dunna ken yeer ain bairn!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Ye never saw the face o' her, sin she hung a wee giglet at the breast! Weel, weel! Nothing comes more surely tul licht than that which is long hidden! An ill life, an ill end!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Wolves, tigers, serpents were first created, and then man!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: You are truly a high fellow, Mordent: you spend your fortune, wrong your wife, and disown your child! That is, you inflict misery and then tell us all are miserable.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I act and I am acted upon. The precept and the proof go together.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: You are incorrigible! But come; we must about this business. My heart is deeply interested.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: My affairs are at a crisis; and, if I augur rightly, it will soon be all over with me.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Hope better. Come; come with me to Enfield's.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I'll meet you there in half an hour.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Do not fail. I am all impatience.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Just so are curs fighting, and thieves in the act of plundering. Man is ever eager on mischief! With what infernal ardor do two armies prepare in the morning, to exterminate each other before noon! Are they not wife? What is it but compressing the sum of evil within an hour, which trembling cowardice would protract through an age?

sp.speaker: CHEVERIL.
sp.p: YOU must let me have the cash directly.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: That is impossible.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: I say, you must. When I have wants and wishes, nothing shall be impossible.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: What if I were to tell him of Joanna? He would pay well.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Twelve hours have I been free, and have not had a taste of pleasure yet! If I do not make haste, I shall grow old before I begin!

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: I should make him my friend; perhaps should get him to myself, and leave old Item in the lurch. 'Tis a rare thought!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Why do you ruminate? Do you doubt me?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Mr. Cheveril!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Well, sir?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Do you love innocence, youth and beauty?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Do I? 'Sdeath, I am dying for them.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: I know where they are to be found.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: You?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: The rarest creature!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Where? Where?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Such pure white and red!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Ay!

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Such moist, ripe, ruddy lips!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, don't drive me mad! Tell me where; where?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: At a certain convenient—

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Indeed? No, no; I have no taste for beauties of this kind.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: See her, and then judge.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Beside, I'll not be unfaithful to my angelic incognita of the Green Park!

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: She is a young untutored thing.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Untutored?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: That I can assure you.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Then depend upon it I'll not be her instructor. How came she in such a place?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: She knows nothing of the place, nor in the least suspects she is in bad company!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Poor dear soul, what rascal sent her there?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Hem! Why, that is, it it it was a kind of accident.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: She is not for me. I want to be a famous wicked fellow, but not by ensnaring the helpless. No, damme, this is not the true way.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Nay, if you will neither ensnare nor accept the already ensnared, you must e'en marry, or starve.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: That is damned hard!

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Ensnared she will be.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Curse me but she shall not.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: What will you do?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Snatch her from danger; provide for her, cherish her!

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Ay, now you say something.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Zounds! Here have I been an age in the possession of eight thousand a year, and have not done one famous good wicked thing yet! It's a damned shame!

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: You will fall in love with her the moment you see her!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p:
To be sure I shall!—No; on recollection, I can't love two at a time. Then if she should tempt me to be wicked? I mean vicious. I love wickedness,
but I hate vice. 'Tis a dirty whirlpool, in which if once a man set his foot he is soon up to his chin.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: 'Tis in Dover-street. I'll furnish you with an introduction.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: You are abundantly civil. An introduction from a usurer to a—Hem! I shall come to preferment!

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: This is the address.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Dover-street.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Yes: Mrs. Enfield,

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Number— (Recollects.) 'Sblood! Why do I stand prating here? I who have been kept fasting from happiness and pleasure so long? Another day will be over and I shall not get a taste of pleasure!

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Nay, I am telling you of a banquet.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Are you? Why then, I have a keen appetite, and a most devouring wish to fall to: so here goes!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: So, Mr. Grime.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Every thing is prepared, Sir: we wait your good leisure.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: You will find Mr. Item in his own room.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: I shall attend you there: we can do not business till you come.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Heigh ho!

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: My uncle desires me to inform, you, Sir, that he has examined the deed, and it is ready for signing.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I am coming.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Had I but any influence with you, Sir, I would intreat, I would conjure you not to execute it.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: A sudden demand may be made, by the first mortgagee; you may be unprovided for payment; equity of redemption will be forfeited; he will foreclose, and the estate will be his at a valuation made fifty years ago, at less than half its present worth.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! 'Twill become his incumbrance, as it has been mine.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Money lenders neglect no advantage.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: And as for conscience or honour—

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Some of them I am afraid, Sir, have very little of either.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: 'Tis in the order of things. Your uncle indeed is a man of integrity; he knows them to be rogues, and warns me of them.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Sir, he—I—He may be a mistaken man, like others. I once again conjure you, Sir, to re-consider the consequence. It is a very serious affair.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Mr. Clement you are wrong: You cherish the fond hope of alleviating misery. Ah!

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Sir, I—My situation is a painful one, but every feeling of honesty and duty compel me to inform you that, when once you have signed this deed, you will be wholly in the grasp of mercenary men, who will pay no respect to former profits, the benefits they have received, or the feelings and distresses of him by whom they have acquired wealth, power, and pride.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: The nephew and the uncle, poor fools, have the misfortune to be honest. Grime, sly villain, is more cunning, and will not forfeit his hope of cutting evil short at the gallows. The deed must be signed; for the money must be had. Yet these cautionings do but strengthen an aversion which, in spite of necessity, I have always felt against this last act of despair.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Mr. Item, you are right: this mortgage is a damned affair. Delay is dangerous; thought is vain; yet I am inclined to think again, before I sign.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: By all means, Sir! I like that! I approve that! Act with your eyes open! Take no rash step! 'Tis what I always say—but mine is a thankless office. Like other officious fools, I can give counsel, but no help. I am sorry to tell you, here is the upholsterer below, who is very insolent, and declares, if he be not paid immediately, he will have an execution in the house before night.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Scoundrel!—Could not you put him off for a week?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: He has been put off too often.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Are there no means by which you might advance me that sum yourself?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Oh, that I could! It would make me the happiest man on earth!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Affectionate soul!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Riches would now indeed be welcome!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Mr. Item, you make me as great a fool as yourself.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: As to the deed, again and again I warn you not to sign it.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Then I will not. Ruin and wretchedness are certain; but the mode of being wretched is in my own choice, and I will not.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Yet, what the devil I shall say to all your other tradesmen I don't know! They are every man of them as clamorous as the upholsterer. I don't believe one of them will wait two days.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Was ever man so pestered?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Here too is a long account that I have just received from your groom at Newmarket; who says he shall soon want even a whisp of hay. For my part, I have not a guinea in hand! I wish I had! Then the impatience of Cheveril? And what the malignant, damned world will say of the defalcation of a guardian there is no foreseeing! Mine is a painful task; for I cannot honestly discharge my conscience, without shewing you both sides of the picture.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ay, ay! Be faithful; follow nature; daub in the dark shades!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Sign you must not!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: At least I will take an hour or two to think of it. Misfortune, disgrace, and approaching infamy sit mocking at me, and I shall soon attain the acmé of misery.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! You won't sign? Indeed, moody master of mine! Ha? But I will send those about your ears that will presently make you!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: This is the street. It must be somewhere hereabout. What a fatiguing affair pleasure hunting is! Oh that I could once more meet my lovely angel; my Green Park Deity! (Examines his card.) This is the number.

div3.head: SCENE VI.
div3.stage: Enter LENNOX from Mrs. ENFIELD'S Door.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Heydey! Lennox?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Cheveril?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Coming from—? You! Who preach refinement of pursuit, and delicacy of enjoyment?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Oh! We preach one thing, we practice another. Beside, were you but to see her!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Her! Who?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: The girl I told you of—The divinest creature—!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: What, here?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: I am all flame!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: In this house?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Yes: but she shall not remain there half an hour. I am going to prepare every thing. I am determined to secure her—.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Honest Grime has given him an introduction too.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Hush! (Joanna throws up the sash, and appears for a moment at the window.) There she is!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Where? I see nobody.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Ah, she's gone again.

sp.speaker: Chev..
sp.p: Oh, but I'll

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Where are you going?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: To leap through the window!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: No, Cheveril; that must not be.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: She is mine.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Yours?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: I have bought an exclusive right to her: paid a hundred pounds down.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Pooh.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: I tell you she is, and shall be mine.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Well, well; if so—

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Come with me!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: No; I can't.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: This is my way.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Nay, but—

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Good bye!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Zounds, my damned blabbing tongue! (Looking after him.) There he flies, the whirligig! Ah! he is out of sight, and all is safe. I must have Mordent's assistance. Where the devil does he loiter? (Looks wistfully at the window.) I'll soon be back though, for fear of accidents.

div3.head: SCENE VII. The House of Mrs. ENFIELD.

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: Betty!

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: Who is it that bounced through the back door in such haste?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I don't know ma'am: a young —Hem!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: I am here, safe: I have tricked him! Your humble servant, Madam. Your name is—?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Enfield,
sp.p: at your service, Sir.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: You keep a—modish magazine, I think.

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: Magazine!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Of ready-made beauty?

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: Well, Sir?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Your acquaintance, honest Mr. Grime, informed me you have a sample of a fine sort.

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: Ah, you are too late!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: My friend Lennox has paid you one hundred pounds. Don't stare; I know the whole. Bring me to the lady, and, if I like her—

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: I am very sorry, sir, but I cannot: my honour won't let me.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Prodigious virtue! Come, come! Lennox is cunning forty; I am foolish one and twenty. He is too old to be a lavish paymaster,

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: Ah, sir, that is your mistake! He is too young! He will pay better as he grows older.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: I have eight thousand a year, and am determined to be a—a—a—wicked dog.

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: Ah, lord love you!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: So see her I must. This is my proof.

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: As Mr. Lennox is your friend, perhaps you have his permission?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Permission? Oh, yes—No! I'll be wicked but not unprincipled: I won't lie! That is a paltry scoundrel vice; no soul in it. Look you, if that sum will not content you, tell me what will?

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: Why, sir, you are such a handsome, charming, pleasant young gentleman, that—if you could spare me another such—?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: To settle accounts with your honour. Well, there.

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: Observe, sir—it is only a short conversation.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Nothing more.

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: No injury to Mr. Lennox?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Never fear.

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: But you must be wary: young as she is, I never saw so cute one!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Never fear, I tell you! I understand such affairs; or soon shall do at least. I'm a young beginner, but a devilish apt scholar! Exit Mrs. Enfield. Now if she be worth carrying off, and I could out-wit Lennox! I! Oh! I should establish my character, for spirit, soul, and intrepidity for ever! I'll not be out of countenance. No, damme, I am determined! I'll—I'll speak, and to the purpose too! I'll be a damned forward, prating, impudent, wicked, dog!

div3.head: SCENE VIII.
div3.stage: Enter Mrs. ENFIELD, leading JOANNA, who follows reluctantly. CHEVERIL turns his back and tries to assume courage.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Really, madam—

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: Ah, my lamb, pray oblige me! He is one of my kindest, best friends.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: You are so sweet a cherub! I must procure my friends the pleasure of your acquaintance! Ah! There's a dove! There's a beauty!—Dear! I forgot my knotting! I will be back in a moment.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.stage: (Not daring to look at Joanna, calls.)
sp.p: Mrs. Enfield!—She is gone!—I should have felt bolder, had she been present.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: It is very strange!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: What does she say?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: First one man, and then another!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Hay? Hem!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Her friends too are all men!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Where the devil now is all my impudence flown?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: But she is so kind, so winning, that I have not the power to deny.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: If I could but turn round—One plunge and it would be over!Turns by degrees. Ma—! Heavens!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Mercy! It is he!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: The very beauty of the Green Park!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: I had almost hoped never to have seen him more!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: This is the luckiest—Lucky? To find her here?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: I have thought of him much too often!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: A creature so divine! Looks of such conscious modesty! And in this place?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Sir—

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Madam— (Aside.) O that I might but touch her lips!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Mrs. Enfield informs me you are one of her best friends.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Me, madam?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Why—That is— (Aside.) No: I'll not deceive her! (Aloud.) I—I never saw Mrs. Enfield before in my life.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Never—?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Never. And I don't care if I never see her again.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Bless me!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Very true, madam. And I—

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Mrs. Enfield!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Stop, madam!—Pardon my presumption, but—I—you—you have so much beauty and modesty—and merit—and—I am such a faltering—bashful booby—that, if you leave me—I shall run mad!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Mad, sir?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Upon my soul I shall, madam! I can't help it! I never was so enchanted, enraptured, and ravished in all my life! And I am very sorry to find you—

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Sorry to find me?

sp.speaker: Chev
sp.p: No, no, no, madam! Glad to find you! Infinitely glad; but not in this house!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: And why, sir?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: I was frantic to think I had lost you!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: How so, sir? We are not acquainted?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: I am sorry for it, madam!—B—b—but I hope we shall be. I have been a very Bedlamite! I could neither eat, drink, nor sleep!—I have dreamed of you every night! You have been in my head, in my heart, in my arms—!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Your arms, sir!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Oh lord, no, madam! No, no!—I—I am talking in my sleep now. I mean—That is—I would not offend you, madam, no, not for ten thousand thrones! Though to find you here is the greatest torment—!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Torment?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: B—b—bliss! I—I—I would say bliss, madam! Bliss ineffable! And if—you would but leave this wicked place—

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: I do not understand you, sir!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Purity of heart is the characteristic of your countenance: I am sure you are innocent; or, if not, I would give worlds that you were!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: This, sir, is the first time we ever spoke together: what have you heard or seen of me that should authorize you to doubt?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Nothing, madam! On my soul, nothing! Every motion, word and look, speak virtue void of blemish! I would lay down my life to prove it, and to rescue you from this bad woman!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: From Mrs. Enfield?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: An odious, vile—!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: You make me half suspect you are as frantic as you describe yourself! She is the most benevolent of women!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Forgive me if I appear intruding; indeed my intention is good; but, how long have you been in this house?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Not four hours.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: And how long acquainted with this woman?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: To-day was the first time I ever saw her.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: She's innocent! She's innocent!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I tell you, I will see her!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! I hear my guardian!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Lennox will be here presently.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: I must not be seen, but for heaven's sake let me speak to you once more!

div3.stage: Retires into a closet, from which he occasionally looks.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Your humble servant, madam. (Aside.) She is indeed beautiful!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: This is the man of the portrait!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: You are acquainted, I believe, with my friend, Mr. Lennox?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: I, sir? Not to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Did he not converse with you this morning?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: I have conversed with two gentlemen this morning: you are the third.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Lovely creature! Can she too be an instrument of malevolence? (Aloud.) I mean a fair gentleman, about forty.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Well, sir; what of him?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Did he—not make proposals?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: To me? Proposals?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ay, madam; on the common subject, the promoting of ill?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: You speak riddles. He talked idly, and perhaps was more unprincipled and insulting than I supposed!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: By heavens, she is an innocent! Nay her countenance would half persuade me there are beings capable of happiness!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Zounds! He looks as if he too would fall in love with her!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Pardon my intrusion, madam: I am a stranger to you, but—

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Not entirely.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Not!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: I have been studying you all the morning.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Me?—You never saw me before!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Yes, I have.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: When? Where?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Here—In effigy.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: What are they about?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: My portrait? (Aside.) How dare the old beldam hang it up in her house?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: It speaks volumes: yet not so much as the original.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Oh that I could hear them!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Indeed! And what does it say, madam? If it speak good, it lies.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Either it indicates falsely or you have flattered, promised, deceived, and betrayed.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Astonishing!—Who?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: More poor girls than one!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Her eyes penetrate to the heart!— (Aloud.) Evil is every where, therefore in me.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: How she gazes at him! 'Sdeath!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: There is a mixture; traits that struggle to be just and good; occasional marks of virtue, but more of moody remorse.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Is this real?—You judge and speak freely, madam, I applaud your sincerity.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: What should I fear? Beside, you have not the features of revenge.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Her understanding and discernment surpass her beauty.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Will they never have done.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: This eye! How often must it have assumed the same deceiving form and meaning, to have impressed these deep lines of artful seduction! How frequently must health, wealth, and principle have been sacrificed, to gratify dishonest passions!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Amazing! So young too!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: You are an unhappy man: for you have not the apathy of folly; you have a sense, a feeling of what you have done.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: I shall go mad!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I have never had faith in sorcery! Is it your profession?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: I have no profession. I am nobody; the child of nobody; a branch lopped off and cast away; that might have grown, but that could find no root. Misfortune and an active spirit, struggling to shake off oppression, have quickened me a little. Other than this I am but a simple girl; and my whole art is to note what I see, and to speak what I think.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Whoever you are, come but with me, and, while I have a morsel, a home, or a heart, you shall share them.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Damme if she shall!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Why, Mr.—!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: She shall have my morsel, my home, and my heart!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: You in this house, sir?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p:
Nay, sir, you in this house, sir? Madam, put no faith in him! You are very right, he is a seducer!
I love you, heart, body, and soul! I'll offer you no wrong! Every proof that the most ardent, purest passion can give, feel, or imagine, shall be yours!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: This house! This house! What is it you mean, gentlemen? Is there contamination in this house?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Vile! Detestable! A place of intrigue!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Heavens!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: How came I, sir, to find you here?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Zounds, sir, how came I to find you here?

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: What have you done, gentlemen, to alarm the young creature in this manner? A little more and she had escaped us all!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Hark you, Mrs. Enfield. At your peril, keep her safe and free from insult till my return!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Insult! If you breathe impurity in her presence, I'll make a general massacre! Let any one take her away, speak to her, or even look at her, while I am gone, and I'll grind you all to powder! (Goes ana hastily returns.) Here! Here are all the bills I have! I'll be back in five minutes! keep her safe and I'll give you a thousand pounds! My name is Cheveril: ten thousand! (Returns.) Cheveril, I say, my whole estate!

sp.speaker: Mrs. En.
sp.p: But, sir! sir!

sp.speaker: GRIME.
sp.p: ONCE for all, Mr. Item, it will not do! So be of a sweet temper.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Why you grumbling old blockhead, what would you have? May you not thank me for every shilling you are worth in the world?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Don't tell me Mr. Item! I am but your scavenger, and you put me to a deal of dirty work.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Here's gratitude! Why, Mr. Grime!

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Item!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Did I not first find you in a miserable garret, in Fullwood's Rents, where you were starving in rags and wretchedness?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Well!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Did I not take you to Monmouth-Street, make you cast your beggar's skin, transform you into something almost human, hire you apartments in the Temple, and pass you on my master for a rich usurer, a damned rogue?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Very true. But you would not let me act my part! You took care to be the damned rogue yourself!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Have I not trusted you, tutored you, taught you your trade, and furnished the tools?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: And do you pretend to bargain, wrangle, and prescribe terms to me?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Yes: I do.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: You do?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: I do. Help yourself how you can.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Here's a villain!

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: You tutored me, you know; you taught me my trade, and furnished the tools.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: You viper! Sting the bosom that fostered you?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: I follow your own example; Mr. Mordent fostered you? There's morality in it.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Oh, damn your morality!

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Be of a sweet temper! Time was I was your slave; you are now mine.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Oh, the rascal!
