sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: I am too deep in your secrets for you to dare discard me; so, I'll have my share.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Your—?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Ay, my!—My full share. So be sweet tempered.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: And who is to find the money?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: You.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: And who is to run the risk?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: You.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: And who is to be prosecuted for usury and collusion.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Cast perhaps for perjury, whipped, imprisoned, and put in the pillory—You.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: And you to run away with half the profits?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Here's justice! Oh, what a damned world do we live in!

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Your fortune is made; you must now help to make mine.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Here's a villain!

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: You must, or I tell.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: What will you tell?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: All!—All the usurious tricks you have practised on Mordent: the arts by which you have cheated him of his estates, pretending that I am the man; your intention to foreclose; your neglect in not paying yourself interest, purposely to rob according to law; your plots to ruin Cheveril; all, all!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: You will tell all this?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Why you fiend! You superlative villain! You cut-throat!

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Hem!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What the hornie de'el do ye stop at? What gars ye swither? I'ze haud my whisht! Yeer confabulation is unco entertaining!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Ah! good Mr. Donald! Here is my old friend, Mr. Grime, has, has— (Aside to Grime.) [You see what your villainy has done!] (Aloud.) He is a good-natured soul, as you know, [Scoundrel!] and he—I—I—

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Ye!—Yas; ye'er a sweet nut, gin ye war well crackt.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: I, I, I was bantering him: trying to, to—[Villain!] but nothing can put him in a passion! [Oh, curse you!] Nothing!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: The fient! Wow! But ye'er a pauky Gilligapus?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Perhaps you want our good master, Mr. Donald?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Aiblins yeer right, auld Clootie.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: He is gone out. Nothing but a joke, Mr. Donald: nothing else.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Noo could I gi' him sic an a gowf o' the hasfet!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Can I, can my dear friend, Mr. Grime [Oh, you thief!] do you any service?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Haud yeer blether, mon!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Can we oblige you any way in the world?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Yas.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: How? How?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Tak compaission o' the booels o' yeer brother, Jack Ketch, and be yeer ain hangman!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: There villain! You see what you have done!

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Is it my fault? I tell you again, you had better be sweet tempered. I shall say no more: you know my mind.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Oh that I could poison him! (Aloud.) Mr. Grime! Mr. Grime!

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Item?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: This quarreling is very foolish.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Oh, ho!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: We are necessary to each other.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: I know it.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Your hand?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: There.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: We are friends?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: If you please.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Well, well— (Aside.) Damn him! How I hate the dog!—Concerning this Berkshire mortgage—

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Ay?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: You shall have twenty per cent. on the premium.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: That won't do!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Thirty!

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: It won't do! Half! The full half!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Hell take him!—Well, well, my dear Grime, the half be it.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Together with my moiety of the thousand, given with Joanna.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Your—? Hem! (Sighs.) You shall; you shall. Are you satisfied?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: On these conditions.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Where is the deed?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: In that bag.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Mordent is coming. I know he will, for I know he shall, sign. But that is not all.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: What more?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: This damned Scotchman will assuredly betray us to him; and Lady Anne's jointure prevents his being so entirely destitute, and powerless, as is necessary,

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: But how is that to be helped?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Easily enough. You must convey information, to her father and relations, that he has a daughter.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Nay, but—

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Hush! Here he comes! I will give you my reasons and instructions when we are alone. Where is the deed?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Here, ready. Hem!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What is the meaning, Mr. Item, that I see that upholsterer, and two other ill-looking followers with him below?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Nay, why ask me? Why knit your brows at me? Can I coin?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Excuse me! I am a hunted bull, and butt at friends and foes!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: The insolent fellow insisted on taking possession; so, thinking you would not wish Lady Anne to know, I prevailed on him and the officer to remain in the hall, till I could speak to you. If I have done amiss, shew me in what.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No, no. I know your zeal. Why will you not advance two thousand pounds, for that and other immediate purposes, and delay signing, Mr. Grime? I ask only a day!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Ay, Mr. Grime, why will you not?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Impossible!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Don't tell me! Impossible, indeed! You ought to consent; it is your duty: nay, you shall consent!

sp.speaker: Crime.
sp.p: I cannot. Must have security.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Villain!—Where is the deed?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: So you will not, Mr. Grime? You will not?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: I wish I could! But I am myself a borrower: the money is not my own.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Hem!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Damn your rascal hypocrisy! Give me the pen!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Why you will not sign, sir! Will you?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Peace, fool! Cannot you see a wretch on the wheel but that your bones too must ach?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Ah! It is always thus! I may advise, but my advice is never followed!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: "I deliver this as my act and deed." Here, implement of hell! I know your thirst, blood hound! 'Tis ready mixed destruction: take, quaff, and burst! Begone!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Come, sir! My good master has sufficient reason to be angry with you! It was very unfriendly, sir, to refuse. You teach Mr. Mordent what he has to expect. (Aside.) All is now secure!

div3.head: SCENE V.
div3.stage: Enter DONALD, looking earnestly after them.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Ha' ye signed?—Ha' ye signed?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ask no questions—Yes.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Weel, weel!—Stark deed has nae remeed!—Twa wolves may worry ane sheep—I kam to tal ye that yeer glib gabbit steward, and his compeer, Grime, are too scoondrels.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Pshaw! Fool!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I tal ye, they are twa damned villains!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Grime, fellow! Grime! A paltry, gold-loving, ravenous rascal! But Item?—a worthy man.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: He wordy? That fient? Marcy o' my soul! He is the prime cock deel o' the blackest pit o' hell! The malison curse catch 'em aw! 'Tis nae stick and flow sax minutes sin I heard aw their murgullied gab!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Hear?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Yas! hear!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What did you hear?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Item himsal confess that he had flethered ye of aw yeer estates; that Grime is nae mair but his flunkie; that it is his intantion to foreclose; that he has wilfully neglacted to pay himsal interest, so that he may claw ye according tul law; that there ha' been sham deeds; and that a plot is laid to felch maister Cheveril of aw his walth.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! You heard all this?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Wi' my ain ears!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Item? Are you sure you heard this precious mischief?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: When did Donald tall ye a lie?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha! Item? I am glad on't! 'Tis right! 'Tis consistent! 'Tis delightful! Ha, ha, ha!
Abraham's rejected prayer: not one honest man. Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Hoot awa! Nae onest? Nor ye nor the black clawed Lucifer himsal canna deny but that Donald is onest.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Item! Ha, ha, ha! Inestimable villain!—And I too? Thought him just and good! Oh, Gull! Gull! Gull! Ha, ha, ha! (Recollecting.) Tell Mr. Clement I wish to speak with him.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Noo the steed is stolen, ye wad steck the door.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Oh the sharp fanged wolf! Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Mordent! How now? How you look!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I am an ass! A most ineffable ass!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! 'Tis proved upon me!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Your mirth is of a strange kind!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: The man whom I have trusted through life, ha, ha! ha, he whose rigid honesty—do you mark me? ha, ha, ha! honesty!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! whose honesty made me sometimes doubt the truth of the self-evident system of evil, ha, ha! he's a rascal! A double leagued hell dog!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Your steward?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Item! A deep damnable thorough-paced villain; that can bully, cajole and curse, fawn, flatter and filch, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Be patient.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Oh I am delighted, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Be calm. You knew yourself to be in the power of a villain, and 'tis little matter whether his name be Grime or Item.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: How? Ha, ha, ha! In a world of rascality, are not two rascals better than one?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Nay but attend to me. I want your help instantly, in Dover-street.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Dover-street?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: It must not be.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Ahey! What's the freak now?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: You can have no help of mine.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Indeed but I must!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I would not commit an injury on that girl for worlds.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Why what conscientious mummery is this? You neglect your own child, and pretend to interest yourself for a stranger!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: If the stranger be an angel of light, a beneficent being, why not?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Beneficent! What, in this system of evil?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: An exception to the rule! A rare exception?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Like Item?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Pshaw! Hell!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: And may not your deserted daughter be equally an angel?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: May she? If she should—I'll have no concern in the ruin of that girl!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Hark you, Mordent, you are plotting.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: No distress can cure you of your old propensities. You mean to trick me of her.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: 'Tis evident. Do you not affirm she cannot remain innocent, in the house into which she is decoyed?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Granted.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Marriage excepted, which would be madness, am I a man to treat her vilely?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Not worse than the malignity of fate ordains.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Pooh! Cant! Cheveril, in the fervor of youth, is lunatic enough rather to marry than lose her.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ay, ay; he is horn mad to begin his career of wretchedness.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: And you his guardian, from pretended pity to a stranger, will guide and spur him to the course?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Even so it is! Mischief here, mischief there; turn which way you will, mischief!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Your word and honour are solemnly pledged-If you really wish the lovely creature's welfare, would preserve your ward, and prove your friendship and honest intentions, you will aid me.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Well, well, I am blind; I am but the tool of destiny; so be it!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Your authority will oblige Mrs. Enfield to yield her to me.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No; my credit there is on the decline. Stratagem; stratagem.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: But how? What?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Convey a disguise to the girl.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: And so she will escape us all!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Escape? No, no! Malevolence is the element of man, and I have an apt alacrity: I will instruct you. Come this way. Having her safe, you may post away with her to my commodious house in Park-lane. Fear not me! When Belial is busy, shall his progeny be idle?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Maister Clement is nae i' the hoose.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No matter— The circle is complete: knaves and fools engender each other; together they make rulers; rulers make laws; laws make villains, and villains sanctify and perpetuate the use of prisons, chains, ropes, racks!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Come, come!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Oh! What an excellent gull is this image of the gods, this thing called man!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Ah! Waes me! This poor lassie? I canna rest! I hirple here and gang hilching there, till I'ze e'en ramfeelzed wi'the ripples. I wist nae where tul spier niest. My dool and thole wull be my deeth! I' Gode's name, and wi' aw my hairt; for I'ze recht weary o' life!

div3.head: SCENE VIII.
div3.stage: Enter CHEVERIL in great haste, searching.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Hoot, man, what is the bang?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: My dear Donald, can you direct me where Mr. Item or Mr. Grime may be found?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Donald diract ye tul sic on a pair o' scoondrels? Father Belzebub! But I wad at anes gar ye o'er catch plague pastilence and faimine!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! they are both dead and buried, I believe; for they are neither here, nor there, nor any where else. Can you tell me where I can borrow a few thousands?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Sir! Do ye tak me for a thief, or a steward?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: I shall go mad—Oh, Donald, I left the most angelic girl your eyes ever beheld at a wicked house! she must be friendless and fatherless, or she could not have been there.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What's that ye red of angil and fatherless?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: I am sure she is innocent. Vile as the house is, she is innocent.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Wha? What she? What hoose?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: I can't say—I saw her first in the Green Park.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Green Park?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: She is now at Enfield's—A divine girl! A miracle!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What? Hoo?—A menzsoo' maikless lass? I' the bloom o' youdith?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Not twenty; yet with the penetration, wit, and understanding of the seven sages!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: The Green Pairk? Maircy misgi' me! Enfield's?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: In Dover-street.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I ken the place! A hoose o'hell!—Gin it be—! Quick, Donald, Quick!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: What is the matter with the honest soul? I don't know what sum that old harridan will require, but I can do nothing without money. I must have enough too, for I must make sure. I'll place her in safety and splendor: she shall be my queen!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Ah, my dear, dear Item! I am the luckiest follow on earth! I am in instant want of money!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: So am I. I have been in want of it all my life.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: You must furnish me with ten thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Ah! I wish I could!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: 'Sblood, don't stand wishing, but give me the money!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: If my friend Grime were but here—

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: 'Sdeath and the devil, give me the money! I shall lose her! She'll be gone! I'll make over the seventeen thousand, that is in Mordent's hands! I will by heaven! On the word and honour of a gentleman!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: The seventeen thousand?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: I will!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: It is true, I have cash in hand; but not my own.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Zounds! Never mind whose it is! Let me have it!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Why, if I could but manage the matter—I am but a poor old man, and it would be a little lift.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Damn your poverty and your cant!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: You are sure you understand—the seventeen thousand?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: I tell you, yes!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: The risk will be very great!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Do you doubt my word?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: No, no—But—

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: But what?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Your hand-writing, on a stamp, would be a memorandum.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: You shall have it! Write a receipt for seventeen thousand: I'll sign it!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.stage: (Searches, takes out an account book, lays it down; then takes out another book, finds a stamp, and writes.)
sp.p: Ay, this is the thing. You remember the risk? Otherwise, it might be thought—

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Give it me! Give it me! I have no time for hinking!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: I must borrow to replace it.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Will you come away, and let me have the money? Come, come, man! 'Sdeath will you dispatch!

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Do you know where Mr. Mordent is, sir?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: No, sir!
sp.stage: (Cheveril burries Item off, who puts up his receipt in one book, but forgets the other, that he laid down on the table.)

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Mr. Mordent has asked for me, and unfortunately I cannot find him. I fear he has signed the mortgage. Oh this uncle! Never was situation so excruciating as mine. Must I cast off all ties of blood, become his accuser, and, as the world would call it, betray my benefactor? Beside, what have I to reveal? My fears and my suspicions. Unconnected facts, that can alarm but not relieve. And who is it that I should thus impotently accuse? My own uncle. (Sees the book.) Hah! What have we here? As I live, his private account book! The very thing he so carefully has concealed from all inspection! What shall I do? Deliver it to Mordent? What may be the consequences? Disgrace, infamy, and—! Dreadful thought! I must not be rash.—Hark! He's here! I must consider well.

div3.head: SCENE XI.
div3.stage: Re-enter ITEM and CHEVERIL. Item with his hair on end, frightened; runs up to the table, looks over it, under it, and every where.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: You see, there is no book there!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: I am certain I had it in my hand!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: We have not quitted the room a minute! Nobody can have been here since!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: We lest my nephew here.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Well, if he have it, 'tis safe enough.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: I don't know that! I don't know that! If I have lost it, I shall never sleep again!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Come away! You have it somewhere, locked up safe.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: No! I laid it down here! I am positive of it!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Nay, but you see that is impossible! Come, come!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: If it be gone, I shall go mad!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Is it so valuable?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.stage: (Still searching his pockets, the table, and the chamber.)
sp.p: I would not lose it for all I am worth in the world!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Come, come— (Elbowing him but not rudely, at first to the door.) What did it contain?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: My soul! My secrets!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Well, it certainly is not here! You must go! You shall go! I'll indemnify you!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: You can't!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: I tell you, I will! (Pushing him off.) It is in your own room.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: I hope so! I hope so! (Turning back.) But my heart misgives me! Oh lord! I'm undone!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Will you go?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: I am wretched!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: You won't!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: I am ruined!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Will you, or—?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: I'm lost! I'm dead! I'm—!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Furies and fire, begone!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Mr. Cheveril! (Runs over to the door.) Mr. Cheveril!—'Tis impossible to stop him! But no matter; the plan cannot fail: Lennox by this time has her safe. Why ay! I have advised! I have plotted, I have aided! And in what? Why the ruin of an innocent; who, while I looked and listened to her, I would have lost my life to defend? Why was man endowed with thought? It breeds but confusion! Fools have called it the gift of gods, wise men know it to be the medium of misery.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar,
sp.p: My lady, sir, desires to know if she may have the honour to see you!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What is the matter now?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: Oh! as to that, let my lady speak! I have got ill-blood enough, because I would not take somebody's part. But that is all over.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What is over?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: I have told my lady, often and often, how a gentleman's proud spirit might be brought down: but she would never listen to my consultation before.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Before?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: For said I, my lady, you would be as merry as May, if you would but pluck up a spirit to take the Earl's advice, and leave all base seducers to their own course!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: You said so?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: Yes, I did! I should be no woman, if I did not take part with my seet! So we are all ready for moving, seeing as we are resolved. For, said I, if he should fall at my feet and cry his eyes out; I would not hear a word!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: Not but I have as tender a heart as another. But then, I would sooner break his heart than my own!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What does this insolent gabble mean?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: Not but I have as tender a heart as another. But then, I would sooner break his heart than my own!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What does this insolent gabble mean?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: Why it means that any lady is coming to take her leave; and that then we shall be gone; and then it will be seen who will have most cause to repent.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: I am sure if I could have made folks happy, I would have done it with all my heart and soul! But the secret is out at last; and all is settled. Not but, for all I'm so glad, I can't say but I'm sorry in the main! for I'm sure some folks will be miserable enough! and, though they richly deserve it, one can't help feeling for them, in ones heart. And so, sir, as perhaps I shall never see you no more, God bless you, and mend you!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Mr. Mordent, I am driven upon an agonizing task, which a too painful sense of duty only could oblige me to execute.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Proceed, Madam; apologies, for feeling or for inflicting pain, are quite unnecessary!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Forgive me! Would it were to be avoided!—You have a daughter?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Whence gain you that intelligence!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: From the Earl of Olderest.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: And what is his authority?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: I know not. But I, it seems, have innocently been the cause that she is disowned and abandoned. Of such an act I cannot knowingly consent to be a moment guilty. The fatal period is come! that separation which I so much have dreaded, is inevitable!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: And you support your fate with patience.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Cruel man! do I deserve this parting reproach?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: You deserve? Who shall dare insinuate it?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Happy days and past endearments rush upon my mind with sensations unutterable?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I know! I know!—I am the vilest of men!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Far from saying, far from thinking so, I take my full share of blame. How do I know that the fault is not wholly mine?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Madam I—I—I request I may be tortured by any thing but your candor.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: I know I have lost the envied art of making myself intelligible to your feelings! And how? You once were happy, tender, and prone to smile at every look and word of mine! Of what fatal errors have I been guilty, that should have wrought this change?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Oh, exquisite! Continue! my nerves are strung!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
To despair of recovering those inestimable blessings was quite sufficient! But to be the cause of banishing a child from a father's arms and heart? to cast it an orphan on a tempestuous world? No! whatever
my other mistakes may have been, of that no tongue shall accuse me!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Right! let the guilt be all my own!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: And now, I have one last request to make; which I conjure you, by all our former affection not to deny!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: To ask favours, where there is neither the power to grant nor the desire to be thanked, is fruitless,

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: I am but too well acquainted with the state of your affairs.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: A humane motive for parting!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: The settlements you have made on me, in our early days of love, were ample. In the sincerity of affection, I vowed, if ever they should be necessary to your happiness, that moment they should again be yours.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Pardon and endure this proof of my fidelity! The deeds are now in Mr. Clement's possession: he will restore them to you.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Never!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Stop! Beware of rashness! You are a father, and have a father's sacred duties to fulfil. Take home your daughter: make her what amends you can for the desertion of a parent's love.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: 'Tis too much! Scorpions could not sting like this!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: On this last occasion, suffer a gleam of former kindness once more to warm your bosom. Money is a poor vehicle, for the affections of the soul! a contemptible token of the love I have borne you! but, such as it is, for that love's sake, give it welcome! A cold adieu I cannot take! It freezes my very heart! From my soul, I ever have loved, and ever shall love! Had I a heaven of happiness to bestow, would you but deign to accept it from me, it should be yours.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Why, so! so! so!—It rages! it bursts! it is complete! Let fate or fiends increase the misery, if they can!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: It's past! It's aw o'er! My forebodings are foofilled!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Have you not found her yet?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Yes, yes! I have foond her!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Have you? Where?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I'ze noo indeed a rasca' go-between! (Horror.) But what are ye?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: You say you have found her?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: She is gone! She is ruined! Ye're a wratch: the most meeserable o' wratches!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Tormenting demon! What? Who?—Where have you been?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: To Dover-street!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Dover—?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Tul the elritch limmer Enfield.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What do you say?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I was too late! A maister scoondrel, e'en as wecked as her ain father, had decoyed her intul his net!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Decoyed?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Lennox! Yeer friend; veer crony!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: From Enfield's!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Ha' not I toud ye?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Lennox? Dover-street? Joanna?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Hear it, gin ye can, and live! Joanna! yeer child! Yeer guilcless Joanna!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Misery of Hell! And was that Joanna? That my child? Celestial creature! And I the pit-digger!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Sir!—Sir!—Maister!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I the pander? I cast her shrieking on the bed of infamy, and chain her in the arms of lust? Her father to do this?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p:
Maister!—Dear Maister!—Maister Mordent! Dear Maister Mordent! Speak! I'ze forgi' ye! Why
maister! I'ze pray for ye! I'ze die for ye! I'ze forgi' ye!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.stage: (Starting from a profound trance of despondency.)
sp.p: Fly! Summon the servants! Arm yourselves! follow me to Park Lane!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: William! Sandy! Jock!

sp.speaker: MORDENT.
sp.p: WE are now in private.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: I am glad we are.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: And now, Sir, I insist on a clear and explicit answer. Where have you lodged Joanna?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, Where have you lodged Joanna?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Mr. Lennox, I will not be trifled with! where is she?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Nor will I be trifled with, Mr. Mordent: I say where is she? The contrivance was your own! I know you! The moment you set your eyes on her you began your cursed plots, to secure her for yourself; and, when you found I would not give her up at your persuasion, you put them in practice while you treacherously pretended to scure her to me.—I tell you, I know you.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: This will not serve, sir, it is all evasion.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Ay, sir, it is evasion! cunning, base, damned evasion! and I affirm she is in your possession.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Mr. Lennox, I am at this moment a determined and desperate man, and must be answered—Where is she?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Sir, I am as determined and as desperate as yourself, and I say, where is she? For you alone can tell?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: 'Tis false!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: False?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ay, false!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: He is the falsest of the false that dares whisper such a word!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Hark you, sir, I understand your meaning, and came purposely provided. (Draws a pair of pistols.) Take your choice. They are loaded.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Oh, with all my heart! (Presents at some paces distant.) Come, sir.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Nigher!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: As nigh as you please!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Foot to foot!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Muzzle to muzzle!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Why don't you fire?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Why don't you unlock your pistol?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: There!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Why do you turn it out of the line?— (Drops his arm. Pause,) I see your intention, Mordent! You are tired of life, and want me to murder you!—Damn it, man, that is not treating your friend like a friend!—Kill me if you will, but don't make me your assassin!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Nay, kill me, or tell me where you have lodged the wretched girl.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Fiends seize me if I have lodged her any where, or know what is become of her.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Your behaviour tells me you are sincere, and to convince you at once that I am no less so, know—she is my daughter!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Your daughter?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: The honest indefatigable Donald discovered her at Enfield's!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Murder my friend, and debauch his daughter.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: We are sad fellows.— (They pause, and gradually recover from the deep passion with which they were mutually seized.) Again and again, 'tis a vile world.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: I'll seek it through with you to find her.—Forgive me?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Would I could forgive myself!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: But it seems then she has escaped, and is perhaps in safety.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Oh that she were!—Donald used to meet her here, in the Green Park, about this time of the evening. (Listens,) I hear the sound of feet. (Looks.) 'Tis not a woman. Let us retire among the trees, and keep on the watch.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: She is not here—she is gone! For ever gone—gone—gone! I shall never more set eyes on her! I'll fire that infernal Dover-street!—I'll pistol Lennox!—I may perambulate here till doomsday, and to no purpose. She would have been here had she been free. Ay, ay, she is in thraldom; perhaps in the very gripe of vice'—Furies!—Lennox is a liar!—I'll cut his throat!—I'll hack him piece-meal!—I'll have her, or I'll have his heart!

div3.head: SCENE III.
div3.stage: Enter JOANNA in men's cloaths. CHEVERIL seen walking among the trees.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Whither shall I run?—Where shall I hide? How fly the pursuits of wicked men, and women still more depraved? I have neither house, home, nor friend on earth; and the fortitude that can patiently endure is my only resource. What then?—Have I not escaped the dens of vice!—Oh happiness!—I have!—I have! And rather than venture in them again, welcome hunger, welcome cold, welcome the bare ground, the biting air, and the society of brute beasts.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: What can that youth want? Why is he watching here?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: As I live the young gentleman I saw this morning! What reason can he have for being in this place?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: He eyes me with curiosity.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: His intentions seemed good, for he first warned me against that wicked woman.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Who can say, he may know her? He is a smart, handsome, dapper fellow: I don't like him.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: I am not now confined by walls and bolts;—there can be no danger.—I'll speak.—Pray, sir—

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Well, sir?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Have you seen a young person—?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: A lady—

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: With blue eyes, auburn hair, aquiline nose, ivory teeth, carnation lips, ravishing mouth, enchanting neck, a form divine, and an angel face?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Have you seen her?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Are you acquainted with that lady?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: I am acquainted with a lady, but not an angel.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Ah! then it is not her. (Jealous) Perhaps you are her—her lover?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Humph—I—I love her.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: You do! (Aside.) I'll be the death of him!—And she loves you?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Why—Yes.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: I'll put an end to him!—Are you married?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: You—you mean to marry her?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Is she then lost to virtue?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Who dare suppose it?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Ay! who dare? I'll cut the villain's throat that dares!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: She has endured insult, constraint, and violence; but not guilt.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Guilt? No; not wilful guilt: impossible! But then—Is she safe? Is she safe?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Disowned by her family, exposed to the snares of vice, houseless, hopeless, not daring to approach the wicked haunts of men, she wanders forlorn and desolate, willing to suffer, disdaining to complain.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Tell me where! I will rescue, defend, protect, cherish, love, adore, die for her!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Is your heart pure? Have you no selfish dishonest purposes?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: How came you to imagine, sir, that I or any man durst couple her and dishonesty, even in a thought?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Meet me here to-morrow at ten.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: You!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: You shall see her.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: See her! Shall I?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: You shall.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: My dear friend! (Catching her in his arms.) I'll make your fortune!—At nine?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Ten.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Could not I see her to-night?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: To-morrow Joanna will meet you.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Joanna? Is that her dear name?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: It is.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Delightful sound! The sweet Joanna! The divine Joanna! My heart's best blood is not so precious as Joanna!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: But pray where do you live?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Joanna!—In Portland-Place.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Your name?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Joanna!—Cheveril: Hans Cheveril.—Joanna!—Be sure you don't forget.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: I'll be punctual.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Who's here

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Joanna!—At eight did not you say?—Where is he gone?—Sir! Sir!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I heard the name repeated! (Aloud.) Who is it here that knows Joanna?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Sir! Do you! Well, and what? Where?—Is she safe?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: I hope so.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: But where, Sir, where?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: 'Tis Mr. Mordent! (Aloud.) Why do you enquire?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: For heaven's sake, Sir, do not torment me by delay, but tell me where she is.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: I must not.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: But, Sir, I say you must, and shall!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Sir, you mistake, if you suppose menaces can prevail.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Excuse me! I would give my right hand to know what it appears you can tell.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: I can tell nothing, 'till I am first made acquainted with your true motives.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: And will you inform me then?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Provided I am certain of their purity.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Know then that I pant for a sight of her once more, to do her the little justice that is yet in my power. Know, the wrongs she has received from me are irreparable, vile, such as could not have happened but in this worst of worlds! Know that I, her natural guardian, have been her actual persecutor; that I drove her to the abode of infamy; that I became the agent of her ruin, the plotter against her chastity; and that, when I had set the engines of darkness and hell at work to ensure her everlasting wretchedness, I then discovered [With horror.] she was my daughter!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Sir!—Your daughter!—You? You my father?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.stage: (Falling at his feet and snatching his hand)
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Can it be?—My child—? —My Joanna? (Eagerly raising and regarding her again.) It is! It is!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: My father!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: My child! And innocent?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: As your own wishes; or the word father should never have escaped my lips! This dress was the disguise conveyed to me, by which I effected my escape. I can suffer any thing but dishonour.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: A father? Oh!—I do not deserve thee! I do not deserve thee! (Gazing rapturously.) Once again, let me sold thee to my heart!

sp.speaker: Len
sp.p: Zounds, sir!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: I insist, sir!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: I hear voices.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Oh for swords, daggers, pistols!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: This way!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Confound your impertinent freaks; they have stopped my mouth this half hour; I would have told you all I knew instantly, but for your insulting passion!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Did not you say you would not tell me where she is?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: I said I could not.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Why there now.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: But I suspect I can tell more at present, if you will but hear.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, then, why don't you?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Will you be silent?—I had a glimpse of Mordent this moment, in conversation with a youth.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: It was the identical dress I sent as a disguise to Joanna.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: And I suspect that very youth to be Joanna herself.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: By heaven, and so it is! (Anger and fear.) In the possession of Mordent?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Be patient—there is a secret—His claims supersede all others.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: His claim!—By every power of heaven and hell—

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Be patient I tell you;—she is his daughter!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Joanna? my sweet Joanna? his daughter?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Even so.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: His daughter? Hurrah! My dear Lennox! (Hugs him in his arms.) Hurrah! (In extacy.) Oh Lord! Oh Lord! Hurrah! His daughter? Hurrah! Hurrah! Hurrah!

div3.head: SCENE VI. The House of MORDENT.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Are you sure it was Mr. Mordent?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: I tell, you, sir, I was on the watch, and opened the door myself. Take care, my dear, said he, to the sham gentleman lady; and handed her in as lovingly!—The monster!—My lady is bewitched!—She is fabricated!—She can't quit the house. I am sure he must have nailed an invisible horse-shoe to the threshold!

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: But how do you know this pretended youth to be a woman?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: Did not I hear? I held the candle full flare in her face; it was a perfect picter! I never saw the like.—So she is to be brought home, truly!—Such magnanimous impudence! But I'll go to my lady.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Be cautious: you may do mischief.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: I don't care! I am resolved to stabilate and confound facts. So then, having a sufficient dearth of proofs, we shall sail off in the charut; and be properly received by the Earl, the Viscount, and the Bishop; and be squired into the hall; and be kissed for joy; and shall swim up stairs into the bosom of the family.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Dear Clement, have you seen Mr. Mordent?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: No:—I am in search of him, on affairs of the utmost importance.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: So am I.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: No less than the recovery or total loss of his mortgaged lands.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: I am in great need of advice, and should be glad to consult you.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Consult!—'Sdeath, man, I am in a hurry! I cannot rest till I have found him.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Nay, but on the decision of the moment his ruin or safety depends.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Indeed! If so, my impatience must wait. What is it?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: I hear footsteps.—This way.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Yes, dear girl, your rare endowments surpass my hopes; and, convinced as I am that beauty is destructive, and wisdom impotent, I joy to find you thus adorned.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Wait to know me better. I fear you should prize me above my worth.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: How shall I reward it? Fool that I am, madman that I have been.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: This is my rich reward!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I have told you in part my desperate situation. If Grime would but give honest evidence—But of that there is little hope.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: My greatest fear arises from what you have said of Lady Anne. I must not, will not be the cause of separation.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Let me do her justice: She is a miracle of forbearance. I have hated and spurned at the kindness I did not deserve. Her perseverance in good has been my astonishment and my torture.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Oh that I could see you reconciled! Oh that I could gain the love of such a lady!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Of that, sweet girl, you are certain. Lennox is with her, and by this she knows your story; and I am sure adores your virtue.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Where is she?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I hear her.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Oh! noble girl! (Runs and embraces Joanna.) Forgive this rude tumult of affection, which I cannot restrain.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Mr. Mordent, you are now a million fold more dear to me.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I cannot bear it!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Will you be my daughter?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Oh, madam!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Will you?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Adversity I could endure, but this unhoped-for tide of blessings overpowers me.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Oh, how I hate myself!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: And why?—Can you be ignorant of the virtuous struggles which have caused the conflict you have felt? The strength of these sensations shew how fitted you are to be great and good.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: To be a—I dare not think!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Indeed you are wrong. Had I not been guilty of a thousand errors, you never would have had occasion for this self reproach. Like cowards, we both have shunned inquiry. Let us be more courageous; let us affectionately communicate our mutual mistakes, and while we examine we shall correct the mind, expand the heart, and render ourselves dear to each other, and beneficent to the whole world.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Oh shame, shame!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Nay, my love—

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: My dear father!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Well, well, I will endure existence a little longer, if it be but to hate myself.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: My life! my soul! my precious Joanna!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: They will persuade me presently that happiness is possible!—You have cause, child, to thank Mr. Cheveril?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Oh, yes! he has a heart of the noblest stamp.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ay! every body right! All angels! except myself: I am cast into the shade; a kind of demon, grinning in the dark!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Come, come, guardian, dismiss these sombre familiars, they have plagued you long enough. Clement is in eager search of you, to communicate secrets of the utmost importance concerning his uncle.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: The villain!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Yes:—he is below, half distracted, foaming with rage, and accusing every servant in the house with having stolen his book! I hear him—Pray keep back! My sweet Joanna, but for a moment.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: 'Tis gone! 'tis lost! I am undone! I am murdered! I am betrayed!—I shall be prosecuted, pilloried, fined, cast in damages, obliged to pay all, to refund all, to relinquish all!—all—all—all! I'll hang myself!—I'll drown myself!—I'll cut my throat!—Mordent has got it!—All my secrets, all my projects, all my rogueries,—past, present, and to come!—Oh that I had never been born!—Oh that—

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Have you seen my book?—Give it me!—Where is my book?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: What book?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: My account book! my secrets! myself! my soul! my heart's blood! (Seizes Clement's coat laps, and searches.) I have it—'tis here—I feel it!

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Yes, sir, 'tis here. Be pacified.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: I won't! I won't! I'll have it! Give it me! I'll swear a robbery! I'll have you hanged!

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.stage: (Takes a book sealed up out of his pocket.)
sp.p: This book, sir, I consider as a sacred trust; and part with it to you I must not.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: You shall part with it, villain! You shall! I'll have your soul! 'Tis mine! I'll have your heart! 'Tis mine! I will have it! I will have it! I will have it!

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: You shall have heart, life, and soul first!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: My dear nephew! My good boy! My kind Clement! I'll supply all your wants! I'll pay all your debts! I'll never deny any thing you ask! I'll make you my heir!

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: You are the agent of Mr. Mordent, whom I fear you have deeply wronged, I have a painful duty to perform; but justice must be obeyed: nothing must or shall bribe me to betray an injured man.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: I'll give you ten thousand pounds! I'll give you twenty! I'll give you fifty! Would you rob and ruin your uncle? Would you put him in the pillory? Would you see him hanged? (Falls upon him again.) Villain! I will have it! 'Tis mine! I will! I will! Thieves! Robbers! Murder! Fire!

div3.head: SCENE the last.
div3.stage: Enter Mr. MORDENT, Lady ANNE, LENNOX, CLEMENT, GRIME, DONALD, JOANNA, and CHEVERIL.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I am glad Mr. Item, that your inattention and your nephew's inflexible honesty have afforded me the means of doing myself justice: that is all I require.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Here is double testimony: your hand-writing and your agent.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Have you impeached then?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: I am a villain, a rascal, a cut throat!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Mr. Clement, your worth and virtue are beyond my praise.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: If my conduct escape censure, it is more than I expect.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: If it meet not retribution, all sense of justice is lost. Donald!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: My watchful guide! My never failing friend!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Your hand, old boy! You and I must settle accounts. I am I know not how many score pounds a year in your debt.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What then am I?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: And I?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Hoot awa! Gin ye wad pay Donald, it mun nae be wi' yeer dirty siller; it mun be wi' yeer affactions.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: True, my noble protector!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Why ay, noo! That's a receipt in foo?—It makes my hairt gi' sic an a bang!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Honest worthy soul. And now to reconcile—

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Come, come; make no speeches. I'll settle the business. I am the proper person. I have eight thousand a year, and ten thousand in my pocket—Ten? (To Item.) Is it ten or seventeen?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Seventeen!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Joanna shall be my queen of joy, pleasure, and happiness. Honesty, here, shall settle all his ill-gotten gains on his nephew: Lennox, as a bachelor's pennance, shall marry his housemaid: You, Guardian, shall change your system of evil for practical good: Lady Anne shall become more patient and kind—if she know how: and old Moloch (To Grime.) shall go hang himself.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Spoken like an oracle.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Why then, toss up your caps, farewel to folly, long life to one and twenty, and mirth, health, and happiness to all!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: How strange are the vicissitudes of fortune! With what gloom was the dawn overcast! How have the storms of this memorable day risen, and increased even to horror! And now how bright the prospect; and how glowing the hope that it excites! Ceerish it, kind friends, with your smiles: and, in the gentle slumbers of the night, let us joyfully dream that we still merit, and still obtain, your willing favour.

div1.head: EPILOGUE.
div1.stage: Mrs. POPE, Miss WALLIS, and Mrs. MATTOCKS come forward.

sp.speaker: Mrs. POPE.
sp.l: AND now, thrice gentle friends, our plotting ended,
We hope you're pleas'd—at least not much offended?
Surely, you'll own it was a little moving,
To see a modern wife so very loving!
Who deems the marriage vow a thing expedient!
And is at once meek! faithful! and obedient!
Such whims were common in the golden age:
And still they may be met with—on the stage:
But grant they now are false, past contradiction,
We hope they yet may be endur'd—in fiction.

sp.speaker: Miss WALLIS.
sp.l: You've heard that good Queen Bess had maids of honour;
Whose courtly trade it was to wait upon her;
To quaff brown stout, yet not be overtaken,
Breakfast on beef, and sup on eggs and bacon?
In those strange days, I can't say what might happen!
Virtue might, then, be thought the woman's weapon!
But daughters now like me, whate'er we feign,
No where exist; but in a poet's brain!
Such blunders are too gross! No soul can brook 'em!
And yet I wish, for once, you'd overlook 'em.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MATTOCKS.
sp.l: Poor Man! He's mad! An heir of one and twenty,
With frolicks, freaks, and pounds and passions plenty,
Who, being told where he may purchase beauty,
Begins to cant of conscience, love, and duty?
Was such stuff ever heard? Ye sprigs of fashion,
Say, is it thus you treat the tender passion?
'Ere such shall come, and prophets shall speak truth!
Yet, put him not in poet's purgatory;
For, should you damn him, we shall all be sorry.

sp.speaker: Miss WALLIS.
sp.p: Then be sweet temper'd!

sp.speaker: Mrs. MATTOCKS.
sp.p: Grant the man his cause!

sp.speaker: Mrs. POPE.
sp.p: And once more make us blest in your applause.
